February 7, 2026

What Startups Taught Me About Running a Modern Sports Facility

Data Marketing Operations Sports

Before I got into tennis coaching, I worked at some of the fastest-moving companies in adtech and marketing technology. Krux Digital (acquired by Salesforce for $700M), Salesforce itself, Advertiser Perceptions, SocialSign.in — these were companies obsessed with data, client acquisition, and engagement.

At the time, I didn't realize how much that experience would shape my thinking about sports operations. But looking back, everything I learned about running a modern business applies directly to running a modern club or facility.

The Data Mindset

At Krux and Salesforce, data wasn't just something we collected — it was how we understood our customers. Every interaction told us something. Every signal was an opportunity to serve people better.

Most sports facilities don't think this way. They track membership numbers and maybe court bookings, but they're not really using data to drive decisions. They're flying blind.

Here's what a data-driven facility looks like:

  • Member engagement tracking — Who's showing up regularly? Who's dropping off? Who's ready for more?
  • Program performance — Which programs fill up? Which ones struggle? What's the actual retention rate for group vs. private lessons?
  • Revenue patterns — When do people buy? What triggers upgrades? What predicts churn?
  • Communication effectiveness — Which emails get opened? Which messages drive action?

You don't need enterprise software to do this. You need the mindset — the habit of asking "what does the data tell us?" before making decisions.

The clubs that win in the next decade will be the ones that treat member data as a strategic asset, not an administrative afterthought.

Client Acquisition Is a System, Not an Event

At startups, we didn't think of sales as one-off transactions. We built systems: lead generation, nurturing, conversion, onboarding, upselling. Every stage was designed, measured, and optimized.

Most sports facilities think of new members as something that just... happens. Someone walks in, or they find you on Google, or a friend refers them. There's no system.

A modern facility should think about client acquisition the same way a SaaS company does:

  • Awareness — How do people in your area discover you exist? (Social media, local SEO, community events, partnerships)
  • Interest — What gets them to take a first step? (Free trial class, open house, introductory offer)
  • Conversion — What turns a trial into a member? (Follow-up sequence, personal outreach, compelling first experience)
  • Retention — What keeps them coming back? (Progress tracking, community, personalized programming)
  • Referral — What motivates them to bring friends? (Referral incentives, shareable moments, word-of-mouth triggers)

Each stage can be measured. Each stage can be improved. That's the difference between hoping for growth and engineering it.

Communication-Driven Engagement

Here's something I learned at Advertiser Perceptions: the best marketing doesn't feel like marketing. It feels like useful communication.

For a sports facility, that means:

Proactive outreach, not just reactive

Don't wait for members to ask questions. Reach out with relevant information before they need it. "Hey, we noticed you haven't booked a court in two weeks — everything okay?" That's not intrusive. That's caring.

Personalization at scale

Use what you know about members to tailor your communication. A beginner getting tips for improving their serve. An advanced player getting info about competitive leagues. A parent getting updates about junior programs. Same facility, different messages.

Multi-channel presence

Email is not enough. Text messages for time-sensitive stuff. Social media for community. App notifications for bookings. Meet people where they are.

Content that builds trust

Share expertise freely. Tips, drills, insights about the sport. Position your facility as a resource, not just a place with courts. When people see you as experts who genuinely want to help them improve, everything else gets easier.

Communication isn't a marketing channel. It's the foundation of member relationships.

Why This Matters Now

The sports facility industry is still surprisingly old-school. Most clubs run the same way they did twenty years ago: put up a sign, hope people show up, try to keep them happy.

But members' expectations have changed. They're used to Netflix knowing what they want to watch. They're used to Amazon remembering their preferences. They expect personalization, proactive service, and seamless experiences.

The facilities that figure this out will dominate their markets. The ones that don't will struggle to understand why their membership keeps declining despite having "great courts."

Bringing It Together

My unusual background — tech startups plus sports operations — gives me a different lens on how facilities should run:

  • Treat data as a strategic asset
  • Build systematic approaches to client acquisition
  • Use communication as a relationship-building tool, not just a promotional channel
  • Apply the operational rigor of fast-moving companies to an industry that's been slow to change

The fundamentals of great sports programming haven't changed. But the way you acquire, engage, and retain members? That's ripe for reinvention.

And I think the people who bridge these worlds — who understand both the sport and modern business operations — are going to be incredibly valuable in the years ahead.
